page.title: 01CLYRO AND DISTRICT
page.content: The district stands astride the Central reaches of the{Wye Valley. It is an ancient borderland extending across the ancient boundary of{Offa's {Dyke.}Today the border between the county of{Hereford and Worcester, in {England,}and the county of{Powys,}in the{Principality of Wales,}bisects the District. The broad Wye valley provides a major routeway into the heartland of {Wales.}The river cuts through the uplands formed by the {Radnor Hills,} to the North, and the {Black Mountains (part of the{Brecon Beacons}) to the South. Its Historical significance is emphasised by the remains of a {Roman {Camp at Boatside and a Norman Castle {in Clyro.} In an area of great natural beauty the Welsh name for Clyro,{Clidderwy,}} means the{Wye on a bed of clay.
